trustfund: TF028065-CANADIAN CONSLT. COOP. PROGRAM,TF023450-CANADIAN CONSULTANT TF FOR ENVIRONMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
The project rendered mixed results, for
            although its outcome is satisfactory, and sustainability is
            likely, both the Bank, and Borrower performances were
            unsatisfactory. While the project correctly identified the
            risk that, recognition of the five coastal wetland sites
            under the Ramsar Convention may not be achieved, it wrongly
            assumed that this could be minimized by the availability of
            project funds for other activities, but project funds did
            not shorten the significant delay in government approvals.
            Therefore, the project overestimated, both the level of
            government ownership, and the availability of counterpart
            funds. Lessons re-emphasize that close involvement with
            stakeholders, and communities ensure the sustainability of
            an operation. Stronger flexibility should have been
            prevalent in the composition of supervision missions, to be
            able to adjust the skills mix, to either legal expertise in
            dealing with the delays in government approvals, or, social
            expertise in developing suitable methods for monitoring
            community-level trends, for the sustainable use of wetland
            resources. Tolerance for weak government agencies'
            performance can be avoided, by limiting agencies to a
            defined policy agenda, and instead channel funds through
            more dynamic, non-governmental organizations, to instead
            submit project concepts for lesser financing, and, smaller
            in scope.
